conclusion: Understanding the problem setup with an equilateral triangle loop moving into a magnetic field.
The loop is an equilateral triangle with side length \(a\) and moves at speed \(v\).
The magnetic field is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of the loop.
The height \(h\) of the triangle is calculated as \(h = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} a\).
As the triangle moves into the magnetic field, changing magnetic flux induces an EMF.
Induced EMF is given by Faraday's law: \(\mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi}{dt}\).
Magnetic flux \(\Phi = B \times A\), where \(A\) is the area within the magnetic field.
Need to find an expression for \(A\) as a function of time.
Position of point \(C\) as a function of time: \(x_C(t) = v t\).
Find the area of the triangle within the field as a function of time.
Consider similar triangles to find the area inside the field.
The height of the portion inside the field is proportional to the distance entered.
Induced EMF is proportional to the rate of change of area inside the field times \(B\).
Find \(A(t)\) using geometry and similar triangles.
